sn4.1:4.2: At one time, when he was first awakened, the Buddha was staying near Uruvelā at the root of the goatherd’s banyan tree on the bank of the Nerañjarā River.
sn4.1:4.3: Then as he was in private solitude this thought came to his mind:
sn4.1:4.4: “I am truly freed from that grueling work!
sn4.1:4.5: Thank goodness I’m freed from that pointless grueling work.
sn4.1:4.6: Thank goodness that, steadfast and mindful, I have attained awakening.”
sn4.1:5.1: And then Māra the Wicked, knowing what the Buddha was thinking,
sn4.1:5.2: went up to him and addressed him in verse:
sn4.1:6.1: “You’ve departed from the practice of mortification
sn4.1:6.3: You’re impure, but think yourself pure;
sn4.1:6.4: you’ve strayed from the path of purity.”
sn4.1:7.1: Then the Buddha, knowing that this was Māra the Wicked, replied to him in verse:
sn4.1:8.2: all that mortification in search of immortality
sn4.1:8.4: as oars and rudder on dry land.
sn4.1:9.2: by developing this path to awakening
sn4.1:10.1: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The Buddha knows me! The Holy One knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.
